{{Infobox automobile | boxcolor = brightred | image = '70 Plymouth Barracuda ('11 Auto classique VAQ Mont St-Hilaire).JPG | caption = 1970 Plymouth Barracuda | name = Plymouth Barracuda | manufacturer = [[Chrysler Corporation]] | production = 1964–1974 | successor = | assembly = {{unbulleted list | [[Fenton, Missouri]] ([[Saint Louis Assembly]])| [[Hamtramck, Michigan]], ([[Detroit/Hamtramck Assembly|Dodge Factory]]) | [[Maywood, California]], ([[Los Angeles (Maywood) Assembly|Los Angeles Assembly]]) | [[Windsor, Ontario]], [[Canada]] ([[Windsor Assembly]]) }} | layout = [[Front-engine, rear-wheel drive layout|FR layout]] | class = [[Pony car]] }} The '''Plymouth Barracuda''' is a two-door [[pony car]] manufactured by [[Plymouth (automobile)|Plymouth]] from 1964 to 1974. The first-generation Barracuda, a [[hardtop]] [[fastback]], was based on the [[Chrysler A platform|A-body]] platform (shared with the [[Plymouth Valiant|Valiant]]). The first generation car featured distinctive wraparound back glass and was marketed from 1964 to 1966. The second-generation Barracuda, built from 1967 to 1969, though still Valiant-based, was heavily redesigned. Body designs were now available in fastback, hardtop [[coupé]], and [[convertible]] versions. The third generation, offered from 1970 to 1974, was no longer based on the A-body, but on the [[Chrysler E platform|Chrysler E-body]]. The completely new design was similar to the [[Dodge Challenger]] and available in hardtop and convertible body styles. The Barracuda was discontinued after the 1974 model year. {{TOC_limit|3}} {{clear}} ==First generation== {{Infobox automobile |name = First generation |image = '66 Plymouth Barracuda (Auto classique Jukebox Burgers '11).jpg |caption = 1966 Plymouth Barracuda |production = 1964–1966 |engine = {{unbulleted list | {{convert|170|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} ''[[Chrysler Slant-6 engine|Slant-6]]'' [[Straight-six engine|I6]] | {{convert|225|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} Slant-6 I6 | {{convert|273|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} ''[[Chrysler LA engine|LA]]'' [[V8 engine|V8]] }} |wheelbase = {{convert|106|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}{{cite book|last=Mueller |first=Mike |title=The Complete Book of Classic Dodge and Plymouth Muscle Every model from 1960 to 1974 |year=2009 |publisher=Motorbooks |isbn=978-0-7603-4477-4}} |length = {{convert|188|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |width = {{convert|70|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |height = {{convert|52.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |weight = {{convert|3100|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} as tested{{cite web |url=http://www.mgphillips.com/zoom/bp2.php |title=Early Barracuda Production Specifications 2 |publisher=mgphillips.com |accessdate=2011-12-22 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20120908070117/http://www.mgphillips.com/zoom/bp2.php |archivedate=2012-09-08 |df= }} |body_style = 2-door [[fastback]] [[coupé|coupe]] |platform = [[Chrysler A platform|A-body]] |related = [[Plymouth Valiant]] }} ===1964=== [[File:1965 Plymouth Barracuda fastbak ivory.jpg|thumb|1965 Plymouth Barracuda]] During development of the Barracuda, one of the worst kept secrets was Ford's plan to introduce a new sporty compact car based on the inexpensive [[Ford Falcon (North America)|Falcon]] chassis and running gear (which was eventually released as the 1964 1/2 [[Ford Mustang|Mustang]]); the extent of the other changes was not known.{{cite book|last=Grist |first=Peter |title=Dodge Challenger & Plymouth Barracuda: Chrysler's Potent Pony Cars |year=2009 |publisher=Veloce Publishing |isbn=9781845841058 |pages=15–22 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=o4wNh7QuIr4C&pg=PA15&lpg=PA15&dq=1964+Barracuda+The+design+for+a+new |accessdate=7 February 2018}} Chrysler stylist Irv Ritchie sketched a fastback version of the compact Valiant, as this body style "has always been considered sporty." Budgets were limited, but the company's executives wanted to have an entry in this quickly growing sporty-compact car market segment and to capture some of the sales from Chevrolet's [[Chevrolet Corvair|Corvair]] Monza models. Plymouth's executives had wanted to name the new model ''[[Giant panda|Panda]]'', an idea unpopular with its designers. In the end, [[John Samsen]]'s suggestion of ''[[Barracuda]]'' prevailed.{{cite web|url= http://cardesign.homestead.com/barracuda.html |first=John "Dick" |last=Samsen |title=Plymouth Barracuda design history |publisher=Cardesign.homestead.com |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120307002749/http://cardesign.homestead.com/barracuda.html |archivedate=2012-03-07 |accessdate=2015-03-29}} Based on Chrysler's A-body,{{cite book |last=Young |first=Tony |title=Mighty Mopars 1960–1974 |publisher=Motorbooks International |year=1984 |page=25 |isbn=978-0-87938-124-0}} the Barracuda debuted in fastback form on April 1, 1964. The new model used the Valiant's {{convert|106|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} wheelbase and the Valiant hood, headlamp bezels, windshield, vent windows, quarter panels, doors, A-pillar, and bumpers; the trunk and some of the glass was new. Utilizing the same hybrid design approach as Ford did turning its Falcon into the Mustang significantly reduced Plymouth's development and tooling cost and time for the new model. The greatest effort was put into creating its distinguishing {{convert|14.4|sqft|m2|2|abbr=on}} rear window, a collaboration between [[PPG Industries|Pittsburgh Plate Glass]] (PPG) and Chrysler designers that created the largest ever installed on a standard production car to that time.''Young'', p. 33 [[Powertrain]]s were identical to the Valiant's, including two versions of Chrysler's [[Chrysler Slant-6 engine|slant-6]] [[Straight-six engine|six-cylinder engine]]. The standard-equipment engine had a [[Engine displacement|displacement]] of {{convert|170|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} and an output of {{convert|101|bhp|kW|abbr=on}}; the {{convert|225|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} option raised the power output to {{convert|145|bhp|kW |abbr=on}}.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} The highest-power option for 1964 was Chrysler's all-new {{convert|273|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Chrysler LA engine|LA V8]]. A compact and relatively light engine equipped with a two-barrel [[carburetor]], it produced {{convert|180|bhp|kW|abbr=on}}.{{cite journal|last=Weertman |first=Willem L. |last2= Beckman |first2=E.W. |title=Chrysler Corp.'s new 273 cu in. V-8 engine |publisher=Society of Automotive Engineers |date=January 1964 |id=640132 |url= http://papers.sae.org/640132/ |accessdate=2010-07-04}} The Barracuda sold for a base price of [[United States dollar|US$]]2,512 (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|2512|1964|r=-3}}}} today). The 1964 model year was the first for the Barracuda and also the last year for push-button control of the optional [[TorqueFlite|Torqueflite]] automatic transmission.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} It also marked the first use of the smaller "TorqueFlite 6" (A904) transmission behind a V8. In the marketplace, the Barracuda was "obviously" a fastback version of the Valiant that had a frugal family transportation image. The sales brochure for the first Barracudas pitched it as a car "for people of all ages and interests." The more "sporty" Mustang was marketed with abundant advertising to young professionals and with its youthful image proved widely successful following its mid-1964 introduction. This became known as the "[[pony car]]" niche of modestly appointed compact-sized sedans and convertibles, which came with standard 6-cylinder engines and basic interiors, but could be outfitted with powerful V8s and "custom" appointments and luxury features. The success of the Mustang has long obscured the fact that the Barracuda actually predated the Ford's introduction by two weeks.{{cite web|url= http://www.allpar.com/model/cuda.html |first=Doug |last=Zwick |first2=Lanny |last2=Knutson |title=The Plymouth Barracuda: First Pony (Fish?) Car |publisher=Allpar |accessdate=2015-03-30}} The abbreviated sales season for the 1964 Barracuda totaled 23,443 units compared to the 126,538 Mustangs sold during the same time. ===1965=== [[File:1965 Plymouth Barracuda Formula S.jpg|right|thumb|1965 Barracuda Formula S]] In 1965, the 225 slant-6 became the base engine for the U.S. market, though the 170 remained the base engine in Canada.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} New options were introduced for the Barracuda as the competition among pony cars intensified. The 273 engine was made available as an upgraded ''Commando'' version with a four-barrel carburetor, 10.5:1 compression, and a more aggressive camshaft, still with solid [[tappet]]s. These and other upgrades increased the engine's output to {{convert|235|bhp|kW|abbr=on}}. Also in 1965, the ''Formula 'S' '' package was introduced. It included the Commando V8 engine, suspension upgrades, larger wheels and tires, special emblems, and a tachometer. Disc brakes and factory-installed air conditioning became available after the start of the 1965 model year.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} ===1966=== [[File:1966 Plymouth Barracuda photo-3.JPG|thumb|1966 Plymouth Barracuda]] For 1966, the Barracuda received new taillamps, new front sheet metal, and a new instrument panel.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} The latter had room for oil pressure and tachometer gauges on models so equipped. The 1966 front sheet metal which, except for the grille, was shared with the Valiant, and gave a more rectilinear contour to the fenders. Deluxe models featured fender-top turn signal indicators with a stylized fin motif. The bumpers were larger, and the grille featured a strong grid theme. A center console was optional for the first time. Although the first Barracudas were heavily based on the contemporary Valiants, Plymouth wanted them perceived as distinct models. Consequently, the "Valiant" chrome script that appeared on the {{frac|1964|1|2}} model's trunk lid was phased out at the end of the 1965 model year in the U.S. market, and the large stylized "V" trim above the deck lid was changed to a unique Barracuda fish logo for 1966, though in markets such as [[Canada]] and [[South Africa]], where Valiant was a marque in its own right, the car remained badged as ''Valiant Barracuda'' until the A-body Barracuda was discontinued.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} {{clear}} ==1967–1969== {{Infobox automobile |name = Second generation |image = Plymouth Barracuda Convertible (Auto classique VAQ Mont St-Hilaire '11).jpg |production = 1967–1969 |body_style = 2-door [[fastback]] [[coupé|coupe]]

[[File:1967-plymouth-barracuda.jpg|thumb|left|1967 Barracuda hardtop]] The new Barracuda was chiefly the work of [[John E. Herlitz]] and [[John Samsen]], with Coke-bottle side contours and heavily revised front and rear ends. Design cues included a concave rear deck panel, wider wheel openings, curved side glass, and S-curved roof pillars on the hardtop. The rear portion of the roof on the fastback [[coupé|coupe]] was more streamlined, and the back glass, raked at a substantially horizontal angle, was much smaller compared with that of the previous model. Also, the use of chrome trim on the external sheet metal was more restrained.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} During this time the first U.S. [[Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard 108|Federal auto safety standards]] were phased in, and Chrysler's response to the introduction of each phase distinguishes each model year of the second-generation Barracuda:{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} *1967: no [[Automotive lighting|sidemarker lamps or reflectors and backup lights on the rear valance by the license plate.]] *1968: round side marker lamps without reflectors, mostly white tail lamps with backup lights in the tail lamp housing. *1969: little tweak on the front grill, rectangular side marker reflectors without lamps, and the backup lamps were moved back to the rear valance by the license plate. As the pony-car class became established and competition increased, Plymouth began to revise the Barracuda's engine options. [[File:1967 Barracuda fastback yellow.jpg|left|thumb|1967 Barracuda fastback]] In 1967, while the {{convert|225|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} slant-6 was still the base engine, the V8 options ranged from the two- and four-barrel versions of the {{convert|273|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} to a seldom-ordered {{convert|383|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Chrysler B engine#383|"B" big-block]], rated at {{convert|280|bhp|0|abbr=on}}, the latter available only with the ''Formula S'' package. [[File:Plymouth Barracuda (Centropolis Laval 2010).jpg|thumb|left|1968 Barracuda]] Some points of interest with the 1967 Cudas were that the front and rear bumpers were identical. They have the same license plate indent and mounting bracket. In 1968, the 273 was replaced by the {{convert|318|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} LA engine as the smallest V8 available, and the new {{convert|340|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} LA four-barrel was released. The 383 Super Commando engine was upgraded with the intake manifold, camshaft, and cylinder heads from the [[Plymouth Road Runner|Road Runner]] and [[Dodge Super Bee|Super Bee]], but the more restrictive exhaust manifolds specific to the A-body cars limited its output to {{convert|300|bhp|0|abbr=on}}.{{cite book |title= Barracuda and Challenger (Muscle Car Color History) |first=Paul |last=Zazarine |publisher=Motorbooks |year=1992 |isbn=978-0-87938-538-5}} Also in 1968, Chrysler made approximately fifty fastback Barracudas equipped with the {{convert|426|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Chrysler Hemi engine|Hemi]] for Super Stock drag racing. These cars were assembled by [[Hurst Performance]] and featured items such as lightweight [[Corning Glass|Chemcor]] side glass, fiberglass front fenders, hood scoop, lightweight seats, sound deadener, and other street features such as rear seats omitted. An included sticker indicated that the car was not for use on public roads; it could run the quarter-mile in the mid-tens in 1968. [[File:1968 Plymouth Barracuda Hardtop Coupe, rear left (Hershey 2019).jpg|thumb|right|1968 Plymouth Barracuda Hardtop]] For the South African export market, a {{convert|190|bhp|0|abbr=on}} high-performance version of the 225 slant-6 called ''Charger Power'' was offered with 9.3:1 compression, two-barrel carburetor, more aggressive [[camshaft]], and low-restriction exhaust system.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} A handful of [[Savage GT]]s were also built from the second-generation Barracuda.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} In 1969, Plymouth placed an increased emphasis on performance. A new option was the ''[[Mod (subculture)|Mod]] Top'', a [[vinyl roof]] covering with a floral motif, available in 1969 and 1970. Plymouth sold it as a package with seat and door panel inserts done in the same pattern.{{cite web|url=http://www.mooresmopars.com/modregistry.html |title=MoPar Mod Top and Mod Interior Registry |publisher=Mooresmopars.com |accessdate=2010-09-07}} The 1969 version of the 383 engine was upgraded to increase power output to {{convert|330|bhp|0|abbr=on}}, and a new [[trim package]] called'' 'Cuda'' was released. The 'Cuda, based on the Formula S option, was available with either the 340, 383 and, new for 1969, the 440 Super Commando V8.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} The successor for this generation of the Barracuda as a sporty [[Plymouth Valiant|Valiant]] was the 1970 [[Plymouth Duster]]. {{clear}} ==1970–1971== {{Infobox automobile |name = Third generation |image = PLYMOUTH BARRACUDA AE-95-62 pic6.JPG |caption=1970 Plymouth 'Cuda |production = 1970–1974 |platform = [[Chrysler E platform|E-body]] |related = [[Dodge Challenger]] |body_style =2-door [[hardtop]] [[coupé|coupe]]

3-speed ''[[TorqueFlite]]'' [[automatic transmission|automatic]] | wheelbase = {{convert|108.0|in|mm|1|abbr=on}}{{cite web |url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Plymouth/1971%20Plymouth/album/1971%20Plymouth%20Barracuda-03.html |title=1971 Plymouth album: |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |accessdate=2013-05-08 }}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} | length = {{convert|186.6|in|mm|1|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|74.9|in|mm|1|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|50.9|in|mm|1|abbr=on}} | weight = {{convert|3395|lb|0|abbr=on}} }} [[File:73 Barracuda MarconiMuseum.jpg|thumb|The 1971 "Sassy Grass" green Plymouth Barracuda housed at the [http://marconimuseum.org/carcollectiongallery/ Marconi Automotive Museum]]] {{more citations needed section|date=December 2012}} The redesign for the 1970 Barracuda removed all its previous [[Automobile platform|commonality]] with the Valiant. The original fastback design was deleted from the line and the Barracuda now consisted of coupe and convertible models. The all-new model, styled by [[John E. Herlitz]], was built on a shorter, wider version of Chrysler's existing [[Chrysler B platform|B platform]], called the [[Chrysler E platform|E-body]].{{cite book|last=Newhardt |first=David |title=Dodge Challenger & Plymouth Barracuda |year=2000 |publisher=MotorBooks International |isbn=9780760307724 |page=42}} Sharing this platform was the newly launched [[Dodge Challenger]]; however no exterior sheet metal interchanged between the two cars, and the Challenger, at {{convert|110|in|0|abbr=}}, had a wheelbase that was {{convert|2|in|mm}} longer than the Barracuda. The E-body Barracuda was now "able to shake the stigma of 'economy car'."{{cite book|last=Newhardt |first=David|title=Dodge Challenger & Plymouth Barracuda|publisher=MotorBooks/MBI |year=2000 |page=7 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=31CLdf2RfFAC&pg=PA7&dq=Barracuda+stigma+of+economy+car+1970 |isbn=978-0-7603-0772-4 |accessdate=2010-07-04}} Three versions were offered for 1970 and 1971: the base Barracuda (BH), the luxury oriented Gran Coupe (BP), and the sport model 'Cuda (BS).[http://www.hamtramck-historical.com/images/dealerships/SalesmansPocketGuides/1970/Pg%20027.jpg] Beginning mid year 1970, and ending with the 1971 model, there also was the Barracuda Coupe (A93), a low-end model which included the 198ci Slant Six as a base engine, lower grade interior, and (like other Coupe series Chrysler Corp. offered that year) had fixed quarter glass instead of roll-down rear passenger windows.[http://www.challengerspecs.com/1970challenger_deputy.htm] The high-performance models were marketed as'' 'Cuda'' deriving from the 1969 option. The E-body's engine bay was larger than that of the previous A-body, facilitating the release of Chrysler's {{convert|426|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Chrysler Hemi engine#Second generation: 426|Hemi]] for the regular retail market.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} [[File:1970 Plymouth Hemi 'Cuda Chrysler France Racing.JPG|thumb|left|1970 Plymouth Hemi 'Cuda, raced by the Chrysler France works team in 1970-1973]] For 1970 and 1971, the Barracuda and Barracuda Gran Coupe had two [[Straight-six engine|six-cylinder engines]] available — a new {{convert|198|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} version of the slant-6, and the 225 — as well as three different V8s: the 318ci, the 383ci with two-barrel carburetor and single exhaust, and the 383ci with four-barrel carburetor and dual exhaust {{convert|330|hp|0|abbr=on}} SAE gross. The Cuda had the 383ci {{convert|335|hp|0|abbr=on}} SAE gross (same as Dodge's 383 Magnum) as the standard engine. It also had the 440ci four-barrel Super Commando, the 440ci six-barrel Super Commando Six Pak, and the 426ci Hemi.{{cite web|url= http://www.plymouthbarracuda.net/information/1970-barracuda-production.shtml |title=1970 Barracuda production totals by powerteam| publisher= Plymouthbarracuda.net |accessdate=2010-07-04}} The 440- and Hemi-equipped cars received upgraded suspension components and structural reinforcements to help transfer the power to the road.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} [[File:1970 Plymouth Cuda 440-6 (15710887687).jpg|thumb|left|1970 Plymouth 'Cuda 440+6 in High Impact Paint (HIP) color "In-Violet"]] In 1970 the power plant options offered to the customer were: #275 hp (200 kW) SAE gross in the 340-4V. #{{convert|335|hp|kW|abbr=on}} SAE gross in the high performance 383-4V, #{{convert|375|hp|kW|abbr=on}} SAE gross in the 440-4V, #{{convert|390|hp|kW|abbr=on}} SAE gross in the 440-6V, and #{{convert|425|hp|kW|abbr=on}} SAE gross in the 426-8V. Other Barracuda options included decal sets, hood modifications, and some unusual "high impact" colors such as "Lime Light", "Bahama Yellow", "Tor Red", "Lemon Twist", "Curious Yellow", "Vitamin C", "In-Violet", "Sassy Grass" and "Moulin Rouge".[http://www.hamtramck-historical.com/paintChipCharts/_1970PaintChipCharts-01.shtml?load_img=1] [[Swede Savage]] and [[Dan Gurney]] raced identical factory-sponsored AAR ([[All American Racers]]) 'Cudas in the 1970 [[Trans-Am Series]]. The cars qualified for three [[pole position]]s but did not win any Trans-Am races; the highest finish was second at [[Road America]].{{cite web |url= http://www.scca.com/documents/Pro%20Racing/Archives/Trans-Am/1970.pdf |title= 1970 Trans-Am Box Scores |publisher= SCCA |accessdate= 2010-07-04 |url-status=dead |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100207055104/http://scca.com/documents/Pro%20Racing/Archives/Trans-Am/1970.pdf |archivedate= 2010-02-07 |df= }} A street version of the AAR 'Cuda was produced, powered by the {{convert|340|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} "Six Pack" (three two-barrel carburetors) engine. Four 1970 Hemi 'Cudas were also successfully raced by Chrysler France, from 1970 until 1973.{{cite web | url= http://blogs.discovery.com/velocity/2012/04/the-french-hemi-cuda-finally-uncovered.html | title=The French Hemi Cuda: Finally Uncovered! |publisher=Velocity |date=2012-04-29 |last=Stephens |first=Bill |accessdate=2013-06-13}} The works team director Henrí Chemin piloted the first car, and then sold it on to friend and privateer J. F. Mas who went on to race it for another two years. This Hemi 'Cuda won four French Group 1 class championships, three on track and one in hill-climbing.{{citation |title=Display board: 1970 Chrysler France Racing Plymouth Hemicuda at the 2013 Greenwich Concours d'Elegance |url= https://www.flickr.com/photos/10047629@N04/9031727415/ | date=2013-06-02 |author=Redline Restorations |accessdate=2015-03-29}} [[File:1971 Plymouth Hemi 'Cuda.jpg|thumb|right|1971 Plymouth Hemi 'Cuda]] The Barracuda was changed slightly for 1971, with a new grille and taillights, seat, and trim differences. This would be the only year that the Barracuda would have four [[headlight]]s (which the Challenger had for all five years of their concurrent run), and also the only year of the fender "gills" on the 'Cuda model.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} The 1971 Barracuda engine options would remain the same as that of the 1970 model, except that the 340 6-Bbl was gone, and the four-barrel carbureted 440 V8 engine was no longer on the option list, but could be had via a special order and perhaps a dozen cars were built with it installed; otherwise the 440-powered Barracudas had a six-barrel carburetor setup instead. In 1971 the big-block power options offered to the customer were: #{{convert|275|hp|kW|abbr=on}} SAE Gross in the 383-2V #{{convert|300|hp|0|abbr=on}} SAE Gross in the 383-4V #{{convert|385|hp|kW|abbr=on}} SAE Gross in the 440-6V #{{convert|425|hp|kW|abbr=on}} SAE Gross in the 426-8V In 1970 and 1971 only, the [[shaker hood]] (option code N96), elastomeric (rubber) colored bumpers, and the Spicer-built [[Dana 60]] rear axle were available. The shaker hood was available with 340, 383, 440 four-barrel, 440 six-barrel, and 426 Hemi engines. The elastomeric (rubber) colored bumpers were available either as a front-only option, option code A21, or as a front and rear combination, option code A22. The heavy-duty (and heavy) Dana 60, with a {{convert|9.75|in|mm|abbr=on}} ring gear, was standard equipment with [[manual transmission]]s and 440 six-barrel and 426 Hemi engines, and was optional on those with the [[automatic transmission]].{{cite web|url=http://www.automobile-catalog.com/car/1970/2687900/plymouth_cuda_hardtop_hemi_torqueflite.html|website=automobile-catalog|title=1970 Plymouth Cuda Hardtop Hemi TorqueFlite|accessdate=July 6, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.automobile-catalog.com/car/1970/2687885/plymouth_cuda_hardtop_hemi_4-speed.html|website=automobile-catalog|title=1970 Plymouth Cuda Hardtop Hemi 4-speed|accessdate=July 6, 2018}} ==1972-1974== [[File:PlymouthBarracuda.jpg|thumb|1972 Plymouth Barracuda]] [[File:1973 Plymouth Barracuda photo-2.JPG|thumb|right|1973 Plymouth Barracuda]] [[File:1973 Plymouth Barracuda (7446283134).jpg|thumb|1973 Plymouth Barracuda interior]] [[File:'74 Plymouth Cuda (Rigaud).JPG|thumb|right|1974 Plymouth 'Cuda]] With a new grille and single headlights (very similar to the 1970 model) and four circular taillights for 1972, the Barracuda would remain basically unchanged through 1974, with new body side stripes, and minor changes to the bumpers to conform with federal impact standards being the only significant variations.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} Big block engines (383, 440, & 426 Hemi), heavy duty suspensions and rear axles, and large/wide tires mounted on 15" x 7" wheels were no longer offered. Additionally; the convertible model was dropped; though a few late build 1971 convertibles were built with 1972 grills and back end panels and provided to Paramount Studios for TV and movie work; being seen on ''[[Mannix]]'', ''[[The Brady Bunch]]'' and other shows. Convenience and comfort items such as power seats, power windows, and upgraded interior (leather seats and plush carpeting) options were dropped, though heavy-duty air conditioning and a sun roof could still be ordered. For 1972 only, three engine choices were offered: a 225 [[Straight-six engine|six]], the 318 (base engine for both 'Cuda and Barracuda), and a revised 340 detuned to meet emission standards. In addition, all three were tuned to run on low/no-lead gas and were power rated on the NET (installed) method. Three transmissions were offered: a 3-speed manual, the [[Torqueflite]] automatic, and the ''[[Hurst Performance|Hurst]]'' shifter equipped four-speed. For 1973 federally mandated safety bumpers were added front and rear, and the 225 six was dropped, with the 318 and 340 V8s being the only engine choices. For late production 1973 cars, and for 1974 a slightly more powerful 360 V8 (245 E bodyhp) replaced the 340. As since 1970; optional was a four-speed manual transmission (equipped with a [[Hurst Performance|Hurst]] shifter) mated to a performance ratio (3.55 to 1) rear axle for the 340 and 360 engines, though as many as three cars (in both 1973 and 1974) were built with the 318 engine and Hurst 4-speed thru special orders or factory errors. As with other American vehicles of the time,{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} there was a progressive decrease in the Barracuda's performance. To meet increasingly stringent safety and [[Automobile emissions control|exhaust emission]] regulations, big-block engine options were discontinued. The remaining engines were detuned year by year to reduce exhaust emissions, which also reduced their power output. There was also an increase in weight as bumpers became larger and, starting in 1970, E-body doors were equipped with heavy steel side-impact protection beams. Higher fuel prices following the [[1973 oil crisis]] and performance-car insurance surcharges deterred many buyers as the interest in high-performance cars waned. Sales of pony cars were on the decline.{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=JHVaQFDrx_MC&pg=RA1-PA1973&dq=sales+of+pony+cars+were+on+the+decline,+with+a+few+exceptions |page=55 |last=Mitchell |first=Larry G. |title=AMC Muscle Cars |year=2000 |publisher=MBI Publishing |isbn=9780760307618 |accessdate=2015-03-30}} Sales had dropped dramatically after 1970, and while 1973 showed a sales uptick, Barracuda production ended 1 April 1974, ten years to the day after it had begun. ===Engines=== {{more citations needed section|date=December 2012}} Engine choices by Chrysler for the (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|1228|1971|r=-3}}}} today) with very few sold. [[Horsepower#SAE gross HP|SAE gross hp]] ratings were tested with no accessories, no air cleaner, or open headers. In 1971, compression ratios were reduced in performance engines, except the 426 cu in and the high performance 440 cu in, to accommodate regular gasoline. 1971 was the last year for the 426 Hemi. Chrysler had plans to continue the 1970 Dodge Challenger T/A for 1971, even publishing advertisements for a 1971 Dodge Challenger T/A. However, no 1971 Dodge Challenger T/A was made. Similarly, no 1971 Plymouth AAR Cuda was made. The 383 Magnum was the standard engine for the 1970 Dodge Challenger R/T, 1970 Dodge Coronet Super Bee, 1970 Plymouth Cuda, and 1970 Plymouth Road Runner; it was not available in any other models.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} ==After 1974== A 1975 Barracuda was planned before the end of the 1970-74 model cycle. Plymouth engineers sculpted two separate concepts out of clay, both featuring a [[Plymouth Superbird|Superbird]]-inspired aerodynamic body, and eventually reached a consensus upon which an operational concept car could be built. Due to a rapidly changing automotive market, the concepts were scrapped, and the 1975 Barracuda was not put into production.{{cite web|url=http://www.popularhotrodding.com/features/0709phr_1975_barracuda/index.html|title=1975 Barracuda - The Fish that Got Away|publisher= Popularhotrodding.com|accessdate=2010-07-04}} The Barracuda was abandoned after 1974, a victim of the [[1973 energy crisis]].{{cite web|url=http://auto.howstuffworks.com/1970-1971-plymouth-barracuda-convertibles.htm |title=1970-1971 Plymouth Barracuda Convertibles |author=Auto Editors of ''Consumer Guide'' |date=2007-07-25| accessdate=2010-09-07}} In 2007, ''[[Motor Trend]]'' magazine reported a rumor that Chrysler was considering reviving the Barracuda in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.motortrend.com/6208266/car-news/chrysler-considering-resurrecting-the-barracuda/index.html |last=Ougarov |first=Kirill | title=Return of the 'Cuda? |publisher=Motor Trend Blogs |date=2007-04-26| accessdate=2010-09-07}} A new Barracuda would've been badged as a [[Chrysler (division)|Chrysler]], due to the Plymouth brand having been phased out in 2001. However, the Barracuda has not been reintroduced alongside the third generation [[Dodge Challenger]]. Rumors of the Barracuda making a comeback were brought up again by ''Motor Trend'' in 2012 when reports leaked that the Barracuda would come back in 2014 under the [[Street and Racing Technology|SRT]] Marque, ''replacing'' the Challenger instead of being built alongside it. It was also stated the car would not be of a retro design.{{cite web |url=https://blogs.motortrend.com/detroits-hottest-rumor-chrysler-to-replace-dodge-challenger-with-a-barracuda-20329.html |first=Todd |last=Lassa |title=Hot Detroit Rumor: Chrysler to Replace Dodge Challenger with a Barracuda! |publisher=Blogs.motortrend.com |date=2012-01-08 |accessdate=2012-02-26 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120610124241/http://blogs.motortrend.com/detroits-hottest-rumor-chrysler-to-replace-dodge-challenger-with-a-barracuda-20329.html |archivedate=2012-06-10 |df= }} Ultimately, the SRT division was re-consolidated under the [[Dodge]] banner and the Challenger remained in production without a Barracuda replacement. After years of silence, an all-new Barracuda, now under the Dodge brand, was shown to [[Fiat Chrysler Automobiles|FCA]] dealers along with other future vehicles on August 25, 2015. Based on stretched underpinnings of the rear-drive [[Alfa Romeo Giulia (952)|Alfa Romeo Giulia]], it is rumored to be powered by a turbocharged V6 and arrive within the 2019 model year.{{cite web|url=http://www.motorauthority.com/news/1099750_barracuda-coming-back-as-a-dodge |first=Joel |last=Feder |title=Barracuda Coming Back As A Dodge? |publisher=Motor Authority |date=2015-08-26 |accessdate=2015-08-27}} ==Collectibility== The Barracuda (particularly the 1970–1974 E-Body cars) is a collectible car today, with the high-performance versions and convertibles commanding the highest prices. The small number of Barracudas remaining in existence is the result of low buyer interest (and low production/sales) when the vehicles were new. The remaining cars of any condition are rare, and the outstanding examples fetch high appraisal values today.{{cite web| url=http://money.cnn.com/2003/06/26/pf/autos/cuda/|last=Valdes-Dapena |first=Peter |title=Million-dollar muscle car? | publisher=CNN/Money.com |date=2003-09-11 |accessdate=2010-09-07}} Original Hemi super stock Barracudas (and similarly configured [[Dodge Dart]]s) are now prized collector vehicles, with factory (unaltered) cars commanding high prices.{{cite web |url=http://www.moparsunlimited.net/barrett_jackson_auction_results_2005.htm |title=Barrett-Jackson auto auction results 2005 |publisher=Mopars Unlimited Car Club Vancouver |accessdate=2010-07-04 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081016092653/http://www.moparsunlimited.net/barrett_jackson_auction_results_2005.htm |archivedate=October 16, 2008 |df= }} The 1971 HemiCuda convertible is now considered one of the most valuable collectible muscle cars. Only thirteen were built, seven of which were sold domestically. The most recent public sale was at the June 2014 Mecum auction in Seattle, where a blue on blue 4-speed sold for [[United States dollar|US$]]3.5 million (plus buyers premium).{{cite magazine|url=https://www.forbes.com/forbeslife/vehicles/2006/11/20/plymouth-hem-barracuda-forbeslife-vehicles-cx_dl_1121vow.html?partner=rssl|title= Covetable 'Cuda|magazine=Forbes |date=2006-11-20 |accessdate=2010-07-04}}{{cite web| url= http://money.cnn.com/gallery/autos/2012/12/17/barrett-jackson-rare-car-auction | title=1971 Hemi 'Cuda Ultra-rare cars going up for auction at Barrett-Jackson | publisher= CNN/Money.com | date=December 17, 2012 | first=Peter |last= Valdes-Dapena |accessdate=2012-12-18}} Several replica cars were created to look like HemiCudas and driven by the [[title character]] in the late-1990s [[police procedural]] ''[[Nash Bridges]]''.{{cite book|page=62 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=yQkLkapJMqwC |chapterurl= https://books.google.com/books?id=yQkLkapJMqwC&pg=PA62&lpg=PA62&ots=83ou_MpfF1&sig=4unNcYIOakYSoTRc9Db1o-_Ey9g&hl=en |title=Challenger and Barracuda 1970-1974 |chapter=Nash Bridges 1971 'Cuda Convertible |year=2010 |first=Jim |last=Schild |series=Collector's Originality Guide Series |isbn=9780760337882 |publisher=MotorBooks International |accessdate=2015-03-30}} None of these replica cars had a Hemi V8 under the hood.{{cite web|url= http://www.motorauthority.com/news/1077305_nash-bridges-1970-plymouth-cuda-convertible-for-sale-on-ebay |title='Nash Bridges' 1970 Plymouth 'Cuda Convertible For Sale On Ebay |first=Kurt |last=Ernst |publisher=Motor Authority |date=2012-06-27 |accessdate=2015-03-30}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{commons {{short description|Type of muscle car manufactured by Plymouth}} {{more citations needed|date=September 2009}} {{Infobox automobile | image = Plymouth Road Runner 1969 5312706.jpg | name = Plymouth Road Runner | assembly = [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] ([[Lynch Road Assembly]])
[[St. Louis]], [[Missouri]] | manufacturer = [[Plymouth (automobile)|Plymouth]] ([[Chrysler]]) | class = [[Mid-size car|Mid-size]] | production = 1968–1980 | related = [[Plymouth Satellite]] | layout = [[FR layout]] }} The '''Plymouth Road Runner''' is a [[mid-size car]] with a focus on performance built by [[Plymouth (automobile)|Plymouth]] in the [[United States]] between 1968 and 1980. By 1968, some of the original [[muscle car]]s were moving away from their roots as relatively cheap, fast cars as they gained features and increased in price. Plymouth developed the Road Runner to market a lower priced, basic trim model to its upscale [[Plymouth GTX|GTX]]. [[File:Plymouth Road Runner 1969 Emblem LakeMirrorClassic 17Oct09 (14598616764).jpg|thumb|Plymouth licensed the Road Runner name, likeness, and "beep beep" sound from the popular Warner Brothers cartoons.]] ==Origin== Plymouth paid $50,000 to [[Warner Bros.-Seven Arts]] to use the Road Runner name and likeness from their [[Wile E. Coyote and the Road Runner]] cartoons (as well as a "[[beep, beep (sound)|beep, beep]]" horn, which Plymouth paid $10,000 to develop).{{cite book|last=Mueller |first=Mike |title=The Complete Book of Classic Dodge and Plymouth Muscle every model from 1960 to 1974 |date=2013 |publisher=Motorbooks |isbn=978-0-7603-4477-4}} The Road Runner was based on the [[Chrysler B platform]] (the same as the Belvedere and Satellite), as a back-to-basics mid-size performance car. == First generation (1968 to 1970) == {{Infobox automobile | name = First generation | image = '69 Plymouth Road Runner (Les chauds vendredis '12).jpg | caption = 1969 Plymouth Road Runner hardtop | production = 1968–1970 | transmission = 3-speed [[Automatic transmission|automatic]]
4-speed [[Manual transmission|manual]] | wheelbase = {{convert|116.0|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}{{cite book|title=Standard Catalog of American Cars 1946-1975|publisher=krause publications|isbn=0-87341-027-0|editor=Gunnell, John A.}} | length = {{convert|202.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} {{cite web|url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Plymouth/1968%20Plymouth/1968%20Plymouth%20Full%20Line%20Brochure/1968%20Plymouth%20Full%20Line-30.html |title=1968 Plymouth Full Line brochure |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-20}} | width = {{convert|76.4|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|54.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} (loaded with 5-passengers) | platform = [[Chrysler B platform|B-body]] | engine = {{convert|383|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} {{convert|335|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} [[V8 engine|V8]]
{{convert|426|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} Hemi V8
{{convert|440|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 | body_style = 2-door [[coupe]]
2-door [[hardtop]]
2-door [[convertible (car)|convertible]] }} ===1968=== [[File:1968 Road Runner green rear.jpg|right|thumb|1968 Road Runner rear view]] [[File:Plymouth Road Runner BW 2016-07-17 13-30-55.jpg|thumb|right|1968 Plymouth Road Runner]] The earliest of the 1968 models were available only as 2-door pillared coupes (with a [[Pillar (car)|B-pillar]] between the front and rear windows), but later in the model year a 2-door "[[hardtop]]" model (sans pillar) was offered. The Road Runner of 1968-1970 was based on the Belvedere, while the GTX was based on the Sport Satellite, a car with higher level trim and slight differences in the grilles and taillights. The interior was spartan with a basic vinyl bench seat, lacking even carpets in early models, and few options were available — such as power steering and front disc brakes, AM radio, air conditioning (except with the 426 Hemi) and automatic transmission. A floor-mounted shifter (for the four-speed) featured only a rubber boot and no console so that a bench seat could be used. The standard engine was an exclusive "Roadrunner" [[Chrysler B engine#383|{{cvt|383|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} B-series]] [[V8 engine]] with a 4-barrel [[Carter Carburetor]] rated at {{convert|335|bhp|PS kW|0|abbr=on}} at 5200 rpm and {{convert|425|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} at 3400 rpm of [[Torque#Machine torque|torque]].{{cite web|url=http://www.automobile-catalog.com/car/1968/2692895/plymouth_road_runner_383_hardtop_4-speed.html|website=automobile-catalog.com|title=1968 Plymouth Road Runner 383 Hardtop 4-speed|accessdate=June 24, 2018}} Its extra {{convert|5|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} rating was the result of using the radical cam from the 440 Super Commando and a .25 raise in compression to 10.5:1 (vs. 10.25:1 with the {{convert|330|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} 383). When air conditioning was ordered, the cars received the {{convert|330|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} version, as the radical cam specs of the {{convert|335|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}} version did not create enough vacuum to accommodate air conditioning. A $714 option was the [[Chrysler Hemi engine#Second generation: 426|{{convert|426|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} Hemi]] with 2X4 [[Carter Carburetor|Carter AFB carburetor]]s rated at {{convert|425|bhp|PS kW|0|abbr=on}} at 5000 rpm and {{convert|490|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} at 4000 rpm of [[Torque#Machine torque|torque]].{{cite web|url=http://www.automobile-catalog.com/car/1970/2696570/plymouth_road_runner_hemi_hardtop_4-speed.html|website=automobile-catalog.com|title=1970 Plymouth Road Runner Hemi Hardtop 4-speed|accessdate=June 24, 2018}} The standard equipment transmission was a 4-speed [[manual transmission]] with floor shifter and the three-speed TorqueFlite [[automatic transmission]] was optional. Early four-speed 1968 Road Runners featured Inland shifters, which were replaced by Hurst shifters during the course of the model year. Plymouth expected to sell about 20,000 units in 1968; actual sales numbered around 45,000. This placed the Road Runner third in sales among muscle cars with only the Pontiac GTO and Chevy's SS-396 Chevelle outselling it. Dodge debuted the Road Runner's cousin, the [[Dodge Super Bee|Super Bee]], as a mid-1968 offering after seeing Plymouth's success with the Road Runner. ===1969=== [[File:1969 Plymouth Road Runner 383.jpg|thumb|1969 Plymouth Road Runner 383]] The 1969 model kept the same basic look, but with slight changes to the [[taillight]]s and [[Grille (car)|grille]], side marker lights, optional [[bucket seat]]s, and new Road Runner [[decal]]s. The Road Runner added a [[convertible]] option for 1969 with 2,128 such models produced that year. All were [[Chrysler B engine#383|{{convert|383|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} engine]] cars, except for ten which were equipped with a [[Chrysler Hemi engine|{{convert|426|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} Hemi]]. An ''Air Grabber'' option (N96 code) was introduced this year; it consisted of a [[fiberglass]] air duct assembly bolted to the underside of the [[Hood (car)|hood]] that connected to twin rectangular upward-facing vents in the hood with rallye red vent screens. The fiberglass hood box had an "Air Grabber" sticker on the front. When the hood was closed, a rubber seal fitted over the large-oval unsilenced air cleaner. A decal with Wile E. Coyote saying "Coyote Duster" was on the [[air cleaner]] lid. The assembly ducted air directly into the engine. The vents in the hood could be opened and closed via a lever under the [[dashboard]] labeled "Carb Air." The 383 engine was standard with the 426 Hemi the only option available for the Road Runner until mid-year production. The 383 was marketed as the "383 Road Runner" engine. The (A12) 440 engine option with 3X2 barrel [[Holley Performance Products|Holley]] [[carburetor]]s was added to the lineup at mid-year. The "440 Six Pack" had no wheel covers or [[hubcap]]s, only the 15x6" "H" stamped steel black wheels with chrome lug nuts. It featured a black fiberglass lift-off hood with 4 hood pins and a large functional [[hood scoop]] with a red sticker on each side saying "440 6BBL". The scoop sealed to the large air breather. All cars had a [[Dana 60]] [[rear axle]] with a 4.10 [[Gear train|gear ratio]]. Production of the 440 6-BBL A12 option Road Runner was approximately 1,432. The A12 option had an "M" as the fifth character in the [[VIN]], rated at {{convert|390|hp|PS kW|0|abbr=on}} at 4,700 rpm and {{convert|490|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} of torque at 3200 rpm,{{cite web|url=http://www.automobile-catalog.com/car/1970/2697500/plymouth_road_runner_440_6-bbl_hardtop_4-speed.html|website=automobile-catalog.com|title=1970 Plymouth Road Runner 440 6-bbl Hardtop 4-speed|accessdate=June 24, 2018}} the same torque as the Hemi but at a lower engine speed. The Plymouth Road Runner was named [[Motor Trend Car of the Year]] for 1969.{{cite book |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=6zSfB-ph6yYC&pg=PA191&dq=Road+Runner+took+home+Motor+Trend's+coveted+Car+of+the+Year+trophy+in+1969 191] |title=The Complete Book of Dodge and Plymouth Muscle |first=Mike |last=Mueller |publisher=Motorbooks |year=2009 |isbn=9780760330791 }} Domestic production for the three body styles was 81,125 with an additional 3,295 deliveries in Canada and other countries.{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=M_Zuroh1si8C&pg=PA168&dq=domestic+production+for+all+three+body+styles+was+81,125+(exports+and+Canadian+deliveries+pushed+that+number+up+to+84,420 |title=Chrysler Muscle Cars: The Ultimate Guide |page=168 |first=Mike |last=Mueller |publisher=Krause |year=2006 |isbn=9780873499705 |accessdate=8 February 2016}} ===1970=== [[File:1970 Plymouth Road Runner.jpg|thumb|1970 Plymouth Road Runner]] The 1970 model year brought new front and rear end looks to the basic 1968 body, and it would prove to be another success. Updates included a new grille, a cloth & vinyl bench seat, hood, front fenders, quarter panels, single-piston Kelsey-Hayes disc brakes (improved from the rather small-rotor Bendix 4 piston calipers of '68 - '69 ), and even non-functional scoops in the rear quarters.{{cite web|url=http://www.autotraderclassics.com/car-article/1970+Plymouth+Road+Runner+-66634.xhtml |title= 1970 Plymouth Road Runner Buyer's Guide |publisher=Autotraderclassics.com|accessdate=2011-11-20}} The design and functionality of the Air Grabber option was changed. A switch below the dash actuated a vacuum servo to slowly raise the forward-facing scoop, exposing shark-like teeth on either side. "High Impact" colors, with names like In-Violet, Moulin Rouge, and Vitamin C, were options available for that year. The engine lineup was left unchanged although a heavy-duty three-speed manual became the standard transmission, relegating the four-speed to the option list along with the TorqueFlite automatic. This was to be the second and last year of the Road Runner convertible, with only 834 made. The new high-back bucket seats shared with other Chrysler products which featured built-in headrests. The 440 Six Barrel remained an option for 1970. The 1969 "M" Code Edelbrock aluminum intake was replaced by a factory-produced cast iron piece; however there were some early cars built prior to January 1, 1970 that were equipped with the left over aluminum Edelbrock intake from the year prior. Sales of the 1970 Road Runner dropped by more than 50 percent over the previous year to around 41,000 units (about 1,000 ahead of Pontiac's GTO but still about 13,000 units behind Chevy's Chevelle SS-396/454). This would also be the last year of the Road Runner convertible with 834 total production. Only 3 Hemi (R) code Road Runner convertibles were built (plus 1 to Canada). The declining sales of Road Runner and other [[Muscle car|muscle cars]] were the result of a move by insurance companies to add surcharges for muscle car policies - making insurance premiums for high-performance vehicles a very expensive proposition. Also, Plymouth introduced another bargain-basement muscle car for 1970, the compact [[Plymouth Duster|Duster 340]] which was powered by a {{convert|275|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} 340 4-BBL V8 which in the lighter-weight compact A-body could perform as well if not better than a 383 Road Runner. Furthermore, the Duster 340 was priced even lower than the Road Runner and its smaller engine qualified it for much lower insurance rates. ===Plymouth Duster I=== The '''Plymouth Duster I''' was a high-performance concept car version of the Road Runner produced in the late 1960s. It featured the usual low-curved racing-type of windshield and had airplane-type flaps on the top and sides. A set of adjustable spoilers on the side of the rear fender (near the gas tank filler cap) helped prevent side-to-side yaw when slipstreaming in a race, with two more of them on top behind the driver, plus spoilers in the front as rock shields to reduce frontal lift. It was powered by a 383 4-BBL V-8.{{cite book |title=Cars Detroit Never Built: Fifty Years of Experimental Cars |author=Edward Janicki |page=113 |isbn=0-8069-7424-9}} == 1970 Superbird == {{main|Plymouth Superbird}} [[File:Plymouth Superbird.jpg|right|thumb|Plymouth Superbird]] During the 1969 NASCAR "aero wars", Chrysler first fielded the Dodge Charger 500 that featured aerodynamic improvements to a standard 1969 Charger. Later in the season Chrysler and Dodge debuted the [[Dodge Charger Daytona]]. The Daytona featured an elevated spoiler raised 23 inches off of the trunk deck by upright pylons and an aerodynamic nose cone. The Charger 500, especially, and the Daytona to a lesser degree struggled to equal the fastback [[Ford Torino Talladega]] and [[Mercury Cyclone Spoiler II]] in 1969. Dissatisfied with the performance of the 1968 Road Runner, [[Petty Enterprises|Petty Engineering]] had asked the Chrysler managers for 1969 Dodge Charger 500s and Charger Daytonas for the 1969 season. The Chrysler managers told the Pettys that they were "a Plymouth team." The Pettys signed with Ford in days and [[Richard Petty]] and Petty Engineering won 10 races in 1969 and finished second in the [[NASCAR]] points championship. To meet NASCAR [[homologation]] rules and also to bring Petty Engineering back to Chrysler, it was decided that Plymouth would get its own version of Dodge's winged wonder for the 1970 NASCAR season. While spectacular {{peacock inline|date=May 2015}} on the track, consumer response was lukewarm, leading a few dealers to remove the wing and nose, making them appear more like normal Road Runners.{{citation required|date=August 2015}} Significantly all public sold Superbirds had vinyl tops, while the Charger Daytonas did not. [[NASCAR]] only required 500 copies to be built in 1969, but in 1970, NASCAR required a manufacturer to build one unit per dealer. Production was 1,935 for the US market. Superbirds were available with three different engines. The most popular was the basic Super Commando 440 V8 with a single four barrel [[carburetor]] rated at {{convert|375|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. Next up was the 440 Six Barrel rated at {{convert|390|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. At the top, and ordered by just 135 buyers, was the 426 Hemi, rated at {{convert|425|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. 135 Hemis (58 4-Spd and 77 Automatics), 1,084 - 440 4-BBL Super Commandos (458 4-Spd and 626 Automatics) and 716 - 440 Six Barrels (308 4-Spd and 408 Automatics). According to Road Test magazine, performance was around 0 to {{convert|60|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on}} in 5.5 seconds, 1/4 mile in 14.3 seconds at 104 mph with the Hemi.{{cite web | url=http://www.aerowarriors.com/sss.html | title=Street Superbird Specifications | accessdate=2008-05-21 }} Although similar in appearance, the Superbird was actually quite different from the Daytona. The Superbird was based on the Plymouth Road Runner and the nose, airfoil, and basic sheet metal was different between the Daytona and Superbird. The Superbird actually used the front fenders and a modified hood from the '70 Dodge Coronet that lent themselves better to the nose design. It was an easy fix due to the fact that the mounting points for fenders on both cars were identical. The special nose added 19-inches (483 mm) to the overall length (the Daytona's was 18-inches or 457 mm), and the trunk spoiler was more angled and higher than the Daytonas. On both models, the spoiler was two feet high. Although it created quite an impression on the street, the wing was not needed at normal highway speeds; it was designed for speedways, to keep the rear wheels to the ground at {{convert|150|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on}} and higher speeds. The reason for using such a tall spoiler was to access 'clean air' according to the engineers who designed the spoiler. In test the spoiler didn't need to be so tall. The spoiler was this tall, to clear the trunk lid. The tallest the spoiler had to be was the same height as the roof.{{cite web|title =The Plymouth Superbird and Dodge Charger Daytona |work=allpar.com |url= http://www.allpar.com/model/superbird.html |accessdate = 2007-05-01 }} Despite the success of the Superbird on the track, 1970 would be the only year it was made. == Second generation (1971–1974) == {{Infobox automobile | name = Second generation | image = 1971 Plymouth Roadrunner (27161774725).jpg | caption = 1971 Plymouth Road Runner 440+6 | production = 1971–1974 | body_style = 2-door [[coupe]] | platform = [[Chrysler B platform|B-body]] | related = {{unbulleted list |[[Plymouth Satellite]] |[[Plymouth GTX]] |[[Plymouth Fury]] |[[Dodge Coronet]] |[[Dodge Charger (B-body)|Dodge Charger]]}} | engine = {{convert|318|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[V8 engine|V8]] (1973, 1974)

3-speed Torqueflite [[Automatic transmission|automatic]] | wheelbase = {{convert|115|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}{{cite web |url=http://www.stockmopar.com/_images/brochures/1971-plymouth-rapid-transit-system-brochure/1971-plymouth-rapid-transit-system-brochure-5.jpg |website=Stock Mopar |title=Specifications: 1971 Road Runner |accessdate=2018-03-08 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150127162823/http://www.stockmopar.com/_images/brochures/1971-plymouth-rapid-transit-system-brochure/1971-plymouth-rapid-transit-system-brochure-5.jpg |archivedate=2015-01-27}} | length = {{convert|203.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|79.1|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|52.9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | weight = {{convert|3640|lb|0|abbr=on}} }} ===1971=== [[File:1971 440 6pack roadrunner engine.jpg|thumb|left|1971 Road Runner 440+6 engine]] In 1971, the coupe bodywork was completely changed to a more rounded "fuselage" design in keeping with then-current Chrysler styling trends, including a steeply raked windshield, hidden cowl, and deeply inset grille and headlights. In a departure from previous thinking, the B-Body two-door bodies shared little if any sheet metal, glass, or trim with the four-door bodies. The convertible was canceled. The interiors could be ordered with 6-way power leather seats, thick deep-pile carpeting, and additional sound-proofing was installed. A/C, and power steering could be had, except on the Hemi. 1971 was a high-water year for ride and handling for the Road Runner. The overall length was increased, but the wheelbase was shortened an inch. It also saw the introduction of the 340 4-BBL option, and a detuned 383 "Road Runner" engine with 8.7:1 compression, and power dropping to {{convert|300|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. In return, Road Runners with the 340 and 383 engine received a standard insurance rating without the costly premiums normally tacked onto muscle cars. The 383 would now run on regular gas.The 440+6 and 426 Hemi were available, though this would be the last year for them. The tall axle ratios with the 8 3/4" Chrysler and Dana 60 rear ends, as well as the wide and close ratio 4-speed transmissions could be had with any of the engine choices, though few cars were built with the ''six-pack'' or ''Hemi'' engines. Aerodynamics were much improved over the first generation Road Runners, resulting in much-improved high-speed handling. ===1972=== 1972 saw new emission regulations drive power down and 1/4 mile times up.[[File:'72 Plymouth Road Runner (Les chauds vendredis '10).jpg|thumb|left|1972 Plymouth Road Runner]]The 1972 model was nearly identical to the 1971 with a few minor changes. The grille design was cleaned up, and the tail lights were changed to match the new aerodynamic look of the grille. Side marker lights changed from the flush mounted side markers to the surface-mounted units that were adopted across the entire Chrysler line-up for the 1972 model year. The optional bumper guards for 1972 included a rubber strip surrounding the tail lights and a rubber strip below the grille. The big differences came in the cutting back of performance options for the car. The suspension, rear axle ratios (a 3:55 ratio was the tallest available), and most noticeably the engines changed, with the big-block 383 being replaced by a larger-bore (and lower performance) 400 CID version as the standard engine. The small-block 340 CID as well as the performance version of the 440 CID engine (with a 4-barrel carburetor, performance camshaft, and dual exhausts) were also available, and for the last time a 4-speed manual transmission could be paired with any of the three engines. All of the engines suffered a drop in compression ratios to allow use of low-lead/no-lead gas and to meet the first round of [[emissions regulations]]. The {{convert|280|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} 440 engine was the basis for the Road Runner GTX (the GTX was no longer a separate model) and was available on Road Runners from 1972 to 1974. The 1971-72 Road Runner sheetmetal was used by several [[NASCAR]] racing teams for their racecars and ran well on the circuit during the 1971-74 seasons. [[Richard Petty]] won the championship both in 1971 and 1972 using the Road Runner-based cars, winning 30 races over the two seasons. For 1972 power ratings on all engines looked much lower on paper due to the new [[Horsepower#SAE net power|SAE net]] measurement system. The famed 426 Hemi was discontinued for 1972, and only five 440 Six Barrel equipped cars were produced before this engine option was dropped (it was determined the 440 six-pack could not meet the stricter 1972 emissions regulations) in the fall of 1971. ===1973–74=== The 1973-74 models received completely new sheet metal and had more conventional squared-up front-end styling and changes to the rear that more closely resembled the four-door models than the 71-72s. In addition, the interior options included retaining power seats and windows as well as offering plusher carpeting and seat covers, moving the car to a slightly higher level of luxury. The restyling helped sales which were up 40% over the 1972 models. In testing 1/4 mile times were getting close to the 16s, top speeds had dropped to barely over {{convert|125|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on}}, and the car moved further away from "musclecar" status. The base engine for the 1973-74 models had dropped down to Chrysler's workaday 318 CID [[V8 engine|V8]] but equipped with dual exhausts which bumped the power up to {{convert|170|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. After 1972, no 440 with [[Manual transmission|four-speed manual]] cars were built. The code E68 400 cu in 260 hp engine was the biggest Plymouth offered with the 4-speed, which could also be had with the 340 (1973), and 360 (1974) engines. The 318 was equipped with a 3-speed manual transmission as standard (though very few were built), and the TorqueFlite as an option, though at least one 318 engine 1974 car was built with the 4-speed manual transmission equipped with a [[Hurst shifter]]. The 440 cu in engine, boasting 280 hp was still available for 1973 and 1974, but only mated to the 727 [[TorqueFlite]] [[Automatic transmission|automatic]], with 3.55 ''sure-grip'' 8 3/4 rear axle gearing available. (Some info from the ''Dodge and Plymouth Muscle Car Red Book'', by ''Motorbooks International.'') File:1973 Plymouth Roadrunner (20608953425).jpg|1973 Plymouth Road Runner File:73 Plymouth Roadrunner (8779418530).jpg|1973 Plymouth Road Runner (rear) File:1974 Plymouth Road Runner 360 - Lucerne Blue, front left (Hershey 2019).jpg|1974 Plymouth Road Runner {{clear-left}} == Third generation (1975) == {{Infobox automobile | name = Third generation | image = File:1975 Plymouth Roadrunner (6073290700).jpg | production = 1975 | wheelbase = {{convert|115|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}{{cite web|url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Plymouth/1975_Plymouth/1975_Chrysler-Plymouth_Brochure/1975%20Chrysler-Plymouth-30.html |title=1975 Chrysler-Plymouth brochure |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-02}} | length = {{convert|213.8|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|77.4|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|52.6|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | weight = {{convert|3500|lb|0|abbr=on}} | body_style = 2-door [[coupe]] | related = [[Plymouth Fury]]

{{convert|360|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8
{{convert|400|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8
{{convert|440|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 | transmission = 3-speed manual
3-speed Torqueflite automatic }} === 1975 === The 1975 model was based on the newly restyled, more formal-looking B-body which was now called the [[Plymouth Fury|Fury]] (the former full-sized Fury being called "[[Plymouth Gran Fury|Gran Fury]]"). Like the Fury, the Road Runner could be ordered with plush interiors, a rally instrument cluster in the dash board, power seats as well as windows. The Road Runner came with a blacked-out grille and a special stripe treatment to distinguish it from the Fury, as well as a heavy-duty suspension with front and rear sway bars, and rallye 14-inch or 15-inch wheels. As before the 318 was the standard engine, but it was now just with a single exhaust and {{convert|145|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. The engine options were however extensive; with a two-barrel/single-exhaust {{convert|170|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} 360, a high-performance four-barrel/dual-exhaust (Code E58) {{convert|220|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} 360, and three 400 CID offerings; a two-barrel/single-exhaust {{convert|160|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}}, a four-barrel/single-exhaust {{convert|185|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}}, and a high-performance (Code E68) four-barrel/dual-exhaust/moderate cam {{convert|235|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} were also available. In ''[[Car and Driver]]'' magazine testing of a 1975 car with the Code E68 400 engine; 0-60 happened in 8.1 seconds, the quarter-mile times were solidly in the 16-second range, and the top observed speed was {{convert|121|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on}}. While just a shadow of the 1970 figures, this performance was at least respectable for the times. All engine choices were limited to the 3-speed ''Torqueflite'' automatic, with the E58 360 and the 400 engines being available with the 3.21 axle ratio gearing. Plymouth's most powerful engine; the 440, was restricted to police models, though it has been rumored that a few 1975 Road Runners were built (via special factory order by checking off the A38 Police Pkge option) with the {{convert|255|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} police spec 440, along with the police spec suspension and wider (7") rims. Only 7,183 Road Runners were built in 1975, and most (just over 50%) had the 318 engine. Although the name of the model the Road Runner was based on changed from Belvedere to Satellite to Fury, the Road Runner remained a B-body through 1975. While the Road Runner name was planned to be on a B-body in Plymouth's published literature for the 1976 model year, the name was transferred to an optional appearance package for the all-new [[Plymouth Volare|Volare]]. ==1976–1980: F-body trim package== [[File:Plymouth Roadrunner (9343628720).jpg|thumb|left|A Volare-based Plymouth Road Runner]] In 1976 the Road Runner name was switched to the 2-door model of the replacement for the [[compact car|compact]] [[Chrysler A platform|A-body]] [[Plymouth Valiant|Valiant]]/[[Plymouth Duster|Duster]] series. The new [[Chrysler F platform|F platform]] was marketed as the [[Plymouth Volaré]] and the new Road Runner became primarily a trim and graphics package. The standard engine was the 318 V8 with the 360 CID V8 offered as an option (with a two barrel carb for 1976-'77 and single exhaust) producing {{convert|160|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and only paired with the three-speed automatic transmission Suspension parts were borrowed from the police packages. In 1978 and 1979, the 360 was offered with a four-barrel carb and, for 1979, dual exhaust, bringing power up to {{convert|195|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. The standard engine for the 1979 model year was the 225 CID "[[Chrysler Slant 6 engine|Slant 6]]" [[Straight-6|six-cylinder]]. For 1980, the 360 was no longer offered, and the 318 was the top engine. The Road Runner continued as part of the Volaré line until its discontinuation in 1980. {{clear}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{commons category inline}} * [https://quatrorodas.abril.com.br/noticias/plymouth-road-runner-o-papa-leguas/ Quatro Rodas] ''in portuguese'' {{Plymouth}} {{Historic Plymouth Timeline}} {{Plymouth Timeline}} [[Category:Plymouth vehicles|Road Runner]] [[Category:Muscle cars]] [[Category:Coupés]] [[Category:Convertibles]] [[Category:Rear-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:1960s cars]] [[Category:1970s cars]] [[Category:1980s cars]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 1968]]
