The Acclaim was [[Plymouth (division)|Plymouth]]'s updated replacement for both the similarly sized [[Chrysler E platform|E-body]] [[Plymouth Caravelle|Caravelle]] and the K-body [[Plymouth Reliant|Reliant]].Chrysler Corporation Master Technician Service Conference book "New Model Service Highlights '89" p.4: "Spirit and Acclaim are the new midsize sedans, replacing 600 and Caravelle." [[Badge engineering]] was employed to give [[Dodge]] and [[Chrysler (division)|Chrysler]] their own versions of the [[Chrysler A platform#AA|AA-body]] Acclaim: the [[Dodge Spirit]], the [[Chrysler LeBaron#1990–1994 sedan|Chrysler LeBaron sedan]], and the export-market [[Chrysler Saratoga]]. It was replaced by the [[Plymouth Breeze]] in 1996. ==Platform== The Acclaim was a version of the [[Chrysler|Chrysler Corporation]]'s [[Chrysler A platform|AA-body]] 4-door sedan, which was an evolutionary development of Chrysler's extended [[Chrysler K platform|K-car platform]]. The Acclaim production ended on December 9, 1994 and the Cab-forward Plymouth Breeze was introduced as a replacement. The Acclaim was one of the last K-car derivatives produced by Chrysler. ==Market positioning== The AA-body cars were [[Badge engineering|badge-engineered]] triplets, as were most Chrysler products of this time. The Acclaim differed from its siblings primarily in wheel choices, bodyside molding, and fascias where it sported its unique taillights and the corporate Plymouth eggcrate-grille. Like the K-body and E-body vehicles they replaced, the Acclaim and Dodge Spirit were both marketed as mainstream variants, while the Chrysler LeBaron was marketed as the luxury variant. Despite this, there was substantial overlap in trims and equipment among each car. For example, a fully loaded Acclaim was almost similar to a base LeBaron in features and price.[http://autos.msn.com/research/vip/pricing.aspx?year=1991&make=Plymouth&model=Acclaim "Plymouth Acclaim Prices"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315222312/http://autos.msn.com/research/vip/pricing.aspx?year=1991&make=Plymouth&model=Acclaim |date=2012-03-15}}, retrieved 2011–01–17. In addition to its entry-level base model, the Acclaim was initially available in mid-range '''LE''' and high-end '''LX''' trim. LE and LX models came equipped with features such including premium cloth seating, power windows/door locks, premium sound systems, bodyside cladding, additional exterior brightwork, and on the latter 15-inch lace-spoke aluminum wheels.Chrysler Corporation Factory Sales Brochure "1990 Plymouth Acclaim" In spite of this, the base model accounted for nearly 85 percent of Acclaim sales.[http://auto.howstuffworks.com/plymouth-cars16.htm "How Plymouth Works: 1990, 1991, 1992 Plymouths" by the Auto Editors of ''Consumer Guide''], retrieved 2011–01–17. Unlike the Spirit, the Acclaim did not receive any sport-oriented models.[http://www.allpar.com/model/acclaim.html "Plymouth Acclaim, Dodge Spirit, Chrysler LeBaron and Saratoga" Information courtesy of Chrysler, allpar], retrieved 2011–01–17. The Acclaim has also been characterized as the replacement for the smaller [[Plymouth Reliant|Reliant]],Fifty Years of American Automobiles, the editors of Consumer Guide, Beekman House 1989, p. 335{{cite web | last =Swern | first =Michael |author2=Aaron Gold | title =K-Chronology - Plymouth Reliant and Dodge Aries, year to year | publisher =Allpar, LLC | date =September 26, 2006 | url =http://www.allpar.com/eek/k/kron.html | accessdate = June 6, 2007}}[http://auto.consumerguide.com/Auto/Used/reviews/full/index.cfm/id/2029/Act/UsedCarReviewShowAll/ Consumer Guide] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060529174405/http://auto.consumerguide.com/Auto/Used/reviews/full/index.cfm/id/2029/act/usedcarreviewshowall/ |date=2006-05-29}} though the [[Plymouth Sundance|Sundance]] launched in 1987 is closer than the Acclaim in most dimensions to the Reliant. ==Changes through the years== [[File:Plymouth-Acclaim.jpg|thumb|right|1989-1990 Plymouth Acclaim]] [[File:1989-92 Plymouth Acclaim LX.jpg|thumb|right|1989-1992 Plymouth Acclaim LX]] [[File:Plymouth Acclaim -- 04-07-2010.jpg|thumb|right|1993-1995 Plymouth Acclaim]] For 1992, the Acclaim's three trim levels were consolidated into one base model. At extra cost, it could be equipped with packages and stand-alone options previously included in LE and LX models. The Acclaim was mildly facelifted for 1993, with a new radiator grille and other minor trim detail changes including a new chrome Pentastar hood ornament. Starting in 1993, the Acclaim was offered with a "Gold Package". This included gold pinstripes, gold bodyside trim, and gold-accented alloy wheels accented with gold paint. There was also a dealer installed "Shelby package" that added an upgraded intake, exhaust manifolds, and fuel pump.{{Citation needed|date=April 2020}} Overall performance of the Shelby Acclaim was comparable to that of the 1993 Ford Mustang and Chevrolet Camaro. There were only 15 Shelby Acclaims said to be produced, and only 11 are still licensed in the United States. Attempting to identify a Shelby Acclaim can be difficult as there is little physical difference in the Shelby and the Gold Package unless seen under the hood. A [[Seat_belt#Automatic_seat_belts|motorized shoulder belt]] was added to the front passenger seating position of [[United States Domestic Market|US-market]] Acclaims in 1994, to comply with Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard 208's requirement for passive restraints. These motorized belts did not comply with [[Canada]]'s safety standards. As a result, Canadian-market Acclaims continued to use a manual passenger seatbelt, and 1994-1995 Acclaims could not be legally imported in either direction.[http://www.riv.ca/english/html/how_to_import.html "Registrar of Imported Vehicles"]. For 1995, its final year, the 2.5-liter engine got a slightly revised cylinder head and the 4-speed A604 automatic transmission and anti-lock brakes were both dropped. Otherwise, the Acclaim remained mostly unchanged during its 6-year run. ===Trim levels=== *base • 1989-1995 *''LE'' • 1989-1992 *''LX'' • 1989-1992 {| border="1" cellpadding="5" cellspacing="0" align="center" |+'''Production FiguresThe Encyclopedia of American Cars, p718-19, 2006 Edition''' |- ! style="background:#C0C0C0;" | Year ! style="background:#C0C0C0;" | Units |- ! align="centered"| 1989 || 77,752 |- ! align="centered"| 1990 || 110,330 |- ! align="centered"| 1991 || 97,146 |- ! align="centered"| 1992 || 77,105 |- ! align="centered"| 1993 || 55,531 |- ! align="centered"| 1994 || 40,294 |- ! align="centered"| 1995 || 12,331 |- ! colspan="2" style="background:#C0C0C0;" | Total Production = 470,489 |} ==Engines== [[File:WhitePlymouthAcclaim.jpg|right|thumb|Plymouth Acclaim LE rear view]] The Acclaim was available with several different engines. A {{convert|2.5|L|cuin|0|abbr=on}} [[Chrysler 2.2 & 2.5 engine|Chrysler inline-4]] engine producing {{convert|100|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} with [[Fuel_injection#Throttle_body_injection|throttle-body fuel injection]] was standard equipment. A {{convert|3.0|L|cuin|0|abbr=on}} [[Mitsubishi 6G7x engine|Mitsubishi V6]] producing {{convert|141|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} with [[MPFI|multi-point fuel injection]] was standard on Acclaim LX, optional on the others. Also available on base and LE models from 1989 through 1992 was a [[Turbocharger|turbocharged]] version of the 2.5-liter four-cylinder producing {{convert|150|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. In 1993, 1994 and 1995, a [[flexible fuel vehicle|flexible-fuel]] Acclaim was offered, powered by a {{convert|107|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} multipoint fuel injected version of the 2.5-liter engine specially modified to run on fuel containing up to 85% [[ethanol]]. ==Transmissions== Several five-speed [[manual transmission]]s were available, depending on which engine was installed, but relatively few Acclaims were equipped with manual transmissions. The three-speed [[TorqueFlite#A413|Torqueflite]] [[Automatic transmission|automatic]] was the most popular installation on Acclaims with TBI and MPFI 4-cylinder engines, and was also widely installed in conjunction with the V6 in 1993 through 1995. From 1989 to 1992, most [[V6]] Acclaims came with the four-speed [[Ultradrive|A604]] electronically controlled [[Automatic transmission|automatic]]. *5-speed [[manual transmission|manual]] *3-speed ''[[TorqueFlite#A413|A413]]'' [[automatic transmission|automatic]] *3-speed ''[[TorqueFlite#A670|A670]]'' [[automatic transmission|automatic]] *4-speed ''[[Ultradrive#A604/41TE|A604]]'' [[automatic transmission|automatic]] ==Discontinuation and replacement== Production ended on December 9, 1994, along with the [[Dodge Spirit]] and the [[Chrysler LeBaron]] after a short run of 1995 models was produced.{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}} Chrysler did not initially replace the Acclaim, but in 1996 released the [[Plymouth Breeze]] version of the [[Chrysler JA platform|JA platform]].[http://www.allpar.com/model/cirrus.html "1995-2000 Dodge Stratus, Plymouth Breeze, and Chrysler Cirrus" Information courtesy of Chrysler, allpar], retrieved 2011–01–18. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Plymouth Acclaim}} * [http://www.imcdb.org/vehicles.php?make=Plymouth&model=Acclaim IMCDB: Plymouth Acclaims in movies & TV shows] * [http://www.allpar.com/model/acclaim.html Allpar Plymouth Acclaim/Dodge Spirit page] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060511185528/http://auto.consumerguide.com/auto/used/reviews/full/index.cfm/id/2089/ ConsumerGuide.com's page on the Acclaim] {{Plymouth}} {{Plymouth Timeline}} [[Category:Plymouth vehicles|Acclaim]] [[Category:Front-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Mid-size cars]] [[Category:Sedans]] [[Category:1980s cars]] [[Category:1990s cars]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 1989]]
